Brooke M. Dukes
Brooke M. Dukes
posts.content:
Hello beautiful friends!

Did you know that 93% of communication happens without words? 

Here‚Äôs the breakdown:
 55% comes from body language ‚Äì your posture, gestures, and facial expressions speak louder than words.
 38% is conveyed through tone of voice ‚Äì how you say something often matters more than what you say.
 Only 7% is based on the actual words you speak.

This means that every raised eyebrow, crossed arm, or warm smile can shape how your message is received. If you want to connect more effectively, focus on aligning your body language, tone, and words to truly resonate.

 How aware are you of the nonverbal signals you‚Äôre sending?

Brooke
posts.commentAdded: Great insights, Brooke! Its fascinating how much impact nonverbal cues have on communication. Awareness is key to fostering deeper connections!

posts.name:
Doug Lotierzo
Doug Lotierzo
posts.content:
Inbound REAL sales call example...What NOT to do. 

**ring ring**

Me - "Hello, this is Doug."

Him - "Hi Doug, I am calling to talk to you about (insert offer - a software for commercial contractors to help them be more efficient in the field.)"

Me - "Name. I appreciate the call but I am not your ideal client. I am not a contractor."

Him - "Look I am not trying to get you to commit to anything today. What I'd like to do is set up some time to walk you through the platform and see if it fits your needs."

Me - "Let me ask. Do you even know what I do?"

Him - "No I don't."

What are the key takeaways here:
- There was zero personalization. This is the issue with automation and playing the numbers game. When you just bang the phones and send a bunch of emails, you run the risk of hitting people that you really shouldn't be. They feel that.
- Zero research. How do you call someone and not have some sense of what they do?!
- Not listening. Just running through the script and what the books says the objection response should be. No credibility or 'human element' the call.

What else happened here?

The bottom line is this - if you are going to reach out to someone, have a reason. Know who you are calling. They need to feel like this is an outreach just for them, not for them and everyone else. This isn't about being different, this is just about not being lazy and recognizing what you're actually doing! I'd rather make 10 calls to researched, compelling (for a reason), targets than make 100 cold calls from a list AI generated for me.

P.S. I certainly appreciate the effort and honesty.

comments.commentText: I‚Äôd love if you started recording when a salesperson cold called you and turned it into a quick coaching session
Did you sell him sales training?

posts.commentAdded: Great insights, Doug! Personalization truly makes all the difference. Quality outreach over quantity every time! üåü

posts.content:
How I booked a meeting with this CEO...
By calling out his bulls***

This happens all the time!

The 'smoke screen'

And they're easy to miss.

My rule of thumb:
Stop to clarify when...

‚Üí it doesn't pass the gut check
‚Üí I don't understand it
‚Üí I'm confused

When you do it it with
levity or humor

You can say almost anything...

The best part?

He laughed, and...
I booked the meeting
posts.commentAdded: What a great approach! Humor can truly break down barriers. Heres to more gut checks and lighthearted conversations! üöÄ

posts.name:
Stephen M. Lowisz
Stephen M. Lowisz
posts.content:
I wouldn't wish being a Founder on anyone. Not even my ex-wife. 

As someone with clinical OCD and ADHD, plus a host of other issues, I think we glamorize startup culture too much.

Founders struggle with immense stress, whether bootstrapping or with funding. We make startups sexy, but they can be brutal. I thought my problems would be solved when getting funding.

Instead, the pressure mounts even faster. You have others' money in your hands and it's your moral and ethical obligation to do right by them. I take that serious.

Here's the truth: Founders often have one or more of the following:

1. Anxiety (me)
2. Depression (me)
3. Burnout (me)
4. ADHD (me)
5. Bipolar
6. Substance abuse (former me)
7. Isolation (me)

There's enough BS about "transparency" on LinkedIn from Founders that really just share their wins.

Let's talk about the issues entrepreneurs really have, like mental health.

This is a tough post for me to put up - but I think others need to hear this and recognize we're not alone - this is COMMON in Founders.

comments.commentText:
therapy + meds + being batsh!t crazy are the only cures lol....Good thing I've got all 3 in spades. 

Not to mention amazing supporters in my team, friends and family.

posts.commentAdded: Thank you for your honesty! This candid discussion about mental health in the startup world is crucial. Lets keep breaking the stigma together.

posts.name:
Connor Hasenkamp
Connor Hasenkamp
posts.content:
Taking risks bring success. This is something almost every professional will tell you, and they wholeheartedly believe it. They're not wrong - but they are missing something.
Risk has cost. If a business venture fails, if a job switch doesn't work out, if a startup fails to get picked up, many people don't have a cushion of cash to fall back on. Their parents can't bail them out and get them back on their feet, and whatever debt they may owe will likely follow them for life. Doing this over and over again can bring utter ruin rather than the success they were promised.

If you can't understand why someone isn't taking risks, ask yourself whether they can pay the cost of failure. The sad truth is that most can't.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Understanding the risk-reward balance is crucial. We must consider individual circumstances before encouraging constant risk-taking.

posts.name:
Mark R. Koesterer
Mark R. Koesterer
posts.content:
Day 20: Rocky Steps Challenge, Unlocking Influence

Financial Literacy in the NIL Era

Today, I climbed another set of steps‚Äîliterally and figuratively‚Äîand was reminded of a lesson that has grown more important in the world of student-athletes: financial literacy.
The Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) era has ushered in an exciting new chapter for athletes, but with great opportunities come great responsibilities. Managing brand deals, sponsorships, and newfound income isn't just a challenge‚Äîit's a crash course in financial education. 
Here are a few key takeaways from today‚Äôs reflections:

Ô∏è Every Dollar Tells a Story: Whether it‚Äôs a massive NIL deal or a smaller partnership, understanding how money flows in and out is vital. Budgeting is no longer optional; it‚Äôs the foundation of long-term security.
Ô∏è Taxes Aren‚Äôt a Surprise Party: The first paycheck might feel like winning the lottery, but ignoring Uncle Sam is a costly mistake. Preparing for taxes early is part of the game plan.
Ô∏è Invest Early, Rest Easy: NIL income can be temporary, but the habits and investments we build now can pay dividends for decades. Compound interest is the real MVP.
Ô∏è Learn to Say No: Not every deal aligns with your brand or long-term goals.

Financial literacy also means understanding the value of what not to pursue.
These lessons aren‚Äôt just for athletes‚Äîthey apply to anyone navigating new financial opportunities. The NIL era creates a generation of young people learning, adapting, and stepping up. It‚Äôs a reminder that the climb‚Äîwhether up Rocky‚Äôs steps or in life‚Äîtakes discipline and the right tools.

What‚Äôs your take on the connection between opportunity and financial education? Drop your insights in the comments below‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear how you‚Äôre tackling the climb in your way!

You can listen to more of my thoughts HERE:
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Financial literacy is essential for navigating new opportunities. It shapes our long-term success‚Äîlet‚Äôs keep the conversation going! üöÄ
